b:["$","script",null,{"type":"application/ld+json","dangerouslySetInnerHTML":{"__html":"{\"@context\":\"https://schema.org\",\"@type\":\"WebSite\",\"name\":\"Expats Argentina\",\"url\":\"https://expatsargentina.com\",\"description\":\"Visa guides, cost of living, and expert advice for expats in all 24 provinces of Argentina.\",\"publisher\":{\"@type\":\"Organization\",\"name\":\"Expats Argentina\",\"url\":\"https://expatsargentina.com\"}}"}}]

d:["$","$1","c",{"children":[null,["$","$L4",null,{"parallelRouterKey":"children","error":"$undefined","errorStyles":"$undefined","errorScripts":"$undefined","template":["$","$L5",null,{}],"templateStyles":"$undefined","templateScripts":"$undefined","notFound":"$undefined","forbidden":"$undefined","unauthorized":"$undefined"}]]}]
15:Td82,{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"FAQPage","mainEntity":[{"@type":"Question","name":"What's the first thing I should do when I arrive in Buenos Aires?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"Get cash and a local SIM card within your first day. Argentina runs on cash, and you'll need pesos immediately for taxis, food, and basic purchases. Get a prepaid SIM from Personal, Movistar, or Claro at any carrier store with your passport. Download WhatsApp before you arrive—everyone uses it here for everything from business to social life."}},{"@type":"Question","name":"How do I get a SIM card in Buenos Aires?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"Visit any Personal, Movistar, or Claro store with your passport and ask for a 'chip prepago' (prepaid SIM). Personal has the best coverage and some English support. Plans start around $5-10/month for basic data. You can top up at kiosks or online. Make sure your phone is unlocked before arriving."}},{"@type":"Question","name":"Can I open a bank account as a tourist in Argentina?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"It's very difficult as a tourist. Most banks require a DNI (Argentine ID) or at minimum a CDI (tax ID). Many expats skip formal banking entirely and use Western Union for transfers, home country credit cards with no foreign transaction fees, and cash for daily expenses. Wait until you have residency or at least a CDI before attempting to open an account."}},{"@type":"Question","name":"How do I find an apartment in Buenos Aires?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"Book an Airbnb for your first 2-3 weeks, then search in person using ZonaProp, MercadoLibre, Facebook groups like 'Expats in Buenos Aires', and by walking neighborhoods looking for 'Alquila' signs. Never commit to a long-term rental before seeing it in person. You'll typically need proof of income, your passport, and 1-2 months deposit. The garantía (local co-signer) requirement is the biggest challenge for foreigners."}},{"@type":"Question","name":"How much cash should I bring to Buenos Aires?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"Bring $2,000-3,000 USD in cash as a buffer for your first month. USD bills get significantly better exchange rates than ATM withdrawals or card payments. Use Western Union to send yourself money for the best rates, or exchange physical dollars at cuevas (exchange houses) recommended by your Airbnb host. Always carry smaller denominations—breaking large bills is difficult."}},{"@type":"Question","name":"What are the most common mistakes new expats make in Buenos Aires?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"The biggest mistakes are: booking a long-term rental before arriving (photos lie), using ATMs for cash (terrible official exchange rate), not learning basic Spanish phrases, staying only in the expat bubble, expecting things to work on a fixed schedule (Argentine time is flexible), and bringing too much stuff from home when most things are available locally."}},{"@type":"Question","name":"What's the realistic budget for the first month in Buenos Aires?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"Expect to spend $1,780-4,260 USD in your first month. This includes temporary accommodation ($600-1,200), apartment deposit ($500-1,500), food and dining ($300-600), transportation ($50-100), phone and internet ($30-60), and miscellaneous expenses ($200-400). Visa fees can add $100-400 if you're applying for residency."}}]}e:["$","$1","c",{"children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"flex flex-col min-h-screen","children":[["$","script",null,{"type":"application/ld+json","dangerouslySetInnerHTML":{"__html":"{\"@context\":\"https://schema.org\",\"@type\":\"BreadcrumbList\",\"itemListElement\":[{\"@type\":\"ListItem\",\"position\":1,\"name\":\"Home\",\"item\":\"https://expatsargentina.com\"},{\"@type\":\"ListItem\",\"position\":2,\"name\":\"First 30 Days\",\"item\":\"https://expatsargentina.com/first-30-days\"}]}"}}],["$","script",null,{"type":"application/ld+json","dangerouslySetInnerHTML":{"__html":"$15"}}],"$L16","$L17","$L18","$L19","$L1a","$L1b","$L1c","$L1d","$L1e","$L1f"]}],["$L20"],"$L21"]}]
f:["$","$1","h",{"children":[null,["$","$L22",null,{"children":"$L23"}],["$","div",null,{"hidden":true,"children":["$","$L24",null,{"children":["$","$25",null,{"name":"Next.Metadata","children":"$L26"}]}]}],["$","meta",null,{"name":"next-size-adjust","content":""}]]}]

Head straight to the official taxi booth (\"Remis\") or book a transfer in advance.\n\n**Best options:**\n- **Tienda León** - Reliable shuttle service, about $15-20 to the city\n- **Uber/Cabify** - Works well, usually $12-18 depending on traffic\n- **Official taxi booth** - Fixed rates, no surprises\n\n**Avoid:** The guys shouting \"Taxi! Taxi!\" inside the terminal. They'll charge double."}]}]]}],["$","div","1",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"font-semibold flex items-center gap-3 text-lg","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"w-10 h-10 rounded-lg bg-primary/10 flex items-center justify-center","children":["$","$L2f",null,{"size":"md","className":"text-primary"}]}],"First Accommodation"]}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"prose prose-sm max-w-none text-muted-foreground whitespace-pre-line","children":"Book an Airbnb for your first 2-3 weeks minimum. 1d:["$","section",null,{"className":"py-16 md:py-24 bg-gray-50","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"max-w-3xl mx-auto px-4","children":[["$","h2",null,{"className":"text-3xl font-bold mb-8","children":"Frequently Asked Questions"}],["$","$L46",null,{"type":"single","collapsible":true,"className":"w-full","children":[["$","$L47","0",{"value":"faq-0","children":[["$","$L48",null,{"className":"text-left","children":"What's the first thing I should do when I arrive in Buenos Aires?"}],["$","$L49",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"Get cash and a local SIM card within your first day. Argentina runs on cash, and you'll need pesos immediately for taxis, food, and basic purchases. Get a prepaid SIM from Personal, Movistar, or Claro at any carrier store with your passport. Download WhatsApp before you arrive—everyone uses it here for everything from business to social life."}]]}],["$","$L47","1",{"value":"faq-1","children":[["$","$L48",null,{"className":"text-left","children":"How do I get a SIM card in Buenos Aires?"}],["$","$L49",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"Visit any Personal, Movistar, or Claro store with your passport and ask for a 'chip prepago' (prepaid SIM). Personal has the best coverage and some English support. Plans start around $5-10/month for basic data. You can top up at kiosks or online. Make sure your phone is unlocked before arriving."}]]}],["$","$L47","2",{"value":"faq-2","children":[["$","$L48",null,{"className":"text-left","children":"Can I open a bank account as a tourist in Argentina?"}],["$","$L49",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"It's very difficult as a tourist. Most banks require a DNI (Argentine ID) or at minimum a CDI (tax ID). Many expats skip formal banking entirely and use Western Union for transfers, home country credit cards with no foreign transaction fees, and cash for daily expenses. Wait until you have residency or at least a CDI before attempting to open an account."}]]}],["$","$L47","3",{"value":"faq-3","children":[["$","$L48",null,{"className":"text-left","children":"How do I find an apartment in Buenos Aires?"}],["$","$L49",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"Book an Airbnb for your first 2-3 weeks, then search in person using ZonaProp, MercadoLibre, Facebook groups like 'Expats in Buenos Aires', and by walking neighborhoods looking for 'Alquila' signs. Never commit to a long-term rental before seeing it in person. You'll typically need proof of income, your passport, and 1-2 months deposit. The garantía (local co-signer) requirement is the biggest challenge for foreigners."}]]}],["$","$L47","4",{"value":"faq-4","children":[["$","$L48",null,{"className":"text-left","children":"How much cash should I bring to Buenos Aires?"}],["$","$L49",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"Bring $2,000-3,000 USD in cash as a buffer for your first month. USD bills get significantly better exchange rates than ATM withdrawals or card payments. Use Western Union to send yourself money for the best rates, or exchange physical dollars at cuevas (exchange houses) recommended by your Airbnb host. Always carry smaller denominations—breaking large bills is difficult."}]]}],["$","$L47","5",{"value":"faq-5","children":[["$","$L48",null,{"className":"text-left","children":"What are the most common mistakes new expats make in Buenos Aires?"}],["$","$L49",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"The biggest mistakes are: booking a long-term rental before arriving (photos lie), using ATMs for cash (terrible official exchange rate), not learning basic Spanish phrases, staying only in the expat bubble, expecting things to work on a fixed schedule (Argentine time is flexible), and bringing too much stuff from home when most things are available locally."}]]}],"$L4a"]}]]}]}]

31:["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"prose prose-sm max-w-none text-muted-foreground whitespace-pre-line","children":"Get connected within your first day. You'll need data for maps, translations, and staying in touch.\n\n**The carriers:**\n- **Personal** - Best coverage, slightly pricier, good English support in some stores\n- **Movistar** - Cheapest, decent coverage, can be spotty in some buildings\n- **Claro** - Middle ground, good city coverage\n\n**Where to buy:** Any carrier store with your passport. Ask for a \"chip prepago\" (prepaid SIM). Plans start around $5-10/month for basic data.\n\n**Pro tip:** Download WhatsApp before you arrive. Everyone uses it here - businesses, landlords, new friends."}]}]
32:["$","div","3",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"font-semibold flex items-center gap-3 text-lg","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"w-10 h-10 rounded-lg bg-primary/10 flex items-center justify-center","children":["$","$L4e",null,{"size":"md","className":"text-primary"}]}],"First Grocery Shop"]}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"prose prose-sm max-w-none text-muted-foreground whitespace-pre-line","children":"You'll need to stock your Airbnb. Here's where locals actually shop:\n\n**Supermarkets:**\n- **Día** - Budget option, basic selection\n- **Carrefour** - Mid-range, good variety, locations everywhere\n- **Jumbo** - Premium, best selection of imported goods\n- **Disco** - Good middle ground, common in nicer neighborhoods\n\n**What to buy first:**\n- Mate (if you're curious) - get a kit with bombilla and yerba\n- Facturas for breakfast - the bakery section has amazing pastries\n- Wine - it's ridiculously cheap and good\n- Subte card (SUBE) - usually at the customer service desk\n\n**Markets:** Find your local \"verdulería\" (produce shop) for fresh fruits and vegetables at half the supermarket price."}]}]]}]
33:["$","div","4",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"font-semibold flex items-center gap-3 text-lg","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"w-10 h-10 rounded-lg bg-primary/10 flex items-center justify-center","children":["$","$L4f",null,{"size":"md","className":"text-primary"}]}],"Finding Your First Meal"]}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"prose prose-sm max-w-none text-muted-foreground whitespace-pre-line","children":"You're tired, hungry, and everything is new. Skip the tourist traps near your Airbnb.\n\n**First-night recommendations:**\n- **El Cuartito** (Talcahuano 937) - Classic pizza, been around since 1934\n- **Las Cuartetas** (Corrientes 388) - Another pizza institution\n- **Any empanada shop on a side street** - Look for places with locals waiting\n\n**Empanada spots to know:**\n- **La Continental** (multiple locations) - Reliable chain\n- **El Sanjuanino** (Posadas 1515) - Traditional, excellent\n- **Ña Serapia** (various) - Open late, perfect for post-flight hunger\n\n**Avoid:** Restaurants with menus in 3 languages and photos of food. They're for tourists."}]}]]}]
34:["$","div","5",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"font-semibold flex items-center gap-3 text-lg","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"w-10 h-10 rounded-lg bg-primary/10 flex items-center justify-center","children":["$","$L2a",null,{"size":"md","className":"text-primary"}]}],"Getting Cash"]}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"prose prose-sm max-w-none text-muted-foreground whitespace-pre-line","children":"This is crucial. Argentina runs on cash, and you'll need pesos immediately.\n\n**Your options:**\n\n1. **Western Union** - Best rates, but locations can have long lines\n   - Download the app, send from your home bank\n   - Pick up at any WU location with your passport\n   - You'll get the \"blue rate\" - significantly better than official\n\n2. **Cuevas (exchange houses)** - Fast, good rates, cash only\n   - Ask your Airbnb host for a recommendation\n   - Count your money carefully\n   - Don't flash cash on the street\n\n3. **ATMs** - Last resort\n   - Terrible rates (official rate)\n   - Low withdrawal limits\n   - Fees add up fast\n\n**Bring USD cash if possible** - you'll get the best rate exchanging physical dollars."}]}]]}]
35:["$","div","6",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"font-semibold flex items-center gap-3 text-lg","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"w-10 h-10 rounded-lg bg-primary/10 flex items-center justify-center","children":["$","$L50",null,{"size":"md","className":"text-primary"}]}],"Basic Spanish Phrases"]}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"prose prose-sm max-w-none text-muted-foreground whitespace-pre-line","children":"You don't need fluency, but these phrases will save you:\n\n**Essentials:**\n- \"No entiendo\" (I don't understand)\n- \"Más despacio, por favor\" (Slower, please)\n- \"¿Cuánto cuesta?\" (How much does it cost?)\n- \"La cuenta, por favor\" (The bill, please)\n- \"¿Dónde está...?\" (Where is...?)\n\n**For taxis/UBER:**\n- \"Derecho\" (straight ahead)\n- \"Aquí está bien\" (Here is fine)\n- \"A la derecha/izquierda\" (To the right/left)\n\n**Shopping:**\n- \"¿Aceptan tarjeta?\" (Do you take card?)\n- \"Solo tengo efectivo\" (I only have cash)\n- \"¿Tiene cambio?\" (Do you have change?)\n\n**Download:** Google Translate with offline Spanish pack. The camera feature reads menus in real-time."}]}]]}]
36:["$","$L2e",null,{"value":"week2","className":"mt-6","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"mb-6","children":[["$","h3",null,{"className":"text-2xl font-bold mb-2","children":"Week 2: Getting Set Up"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"Now that you're rested, tackle the bigger tasks. Finding housing, dealing with bureaucracy, and setting up your life."}]]}],["$","div",null,{"className":"space-y-6","children":[["$","div","0",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"font-semibold flex items-center gap-3 text-lg","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"w-10 h-10 rounded-lg bg-primary/10 flex items-center justify-center","children":["$","$L51",null,{"size":"md","className":"text-primary"}]}],"Finding an Apartment"]}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"prose prose-sm max-w-none text-muted-foreground whitespace-pre-line","children":"Now that you're rested, start the real apartment hunt. This takes 1-3 weeks typically.\n\n**Where to search:**\n- **ZonaProp** - Biggest selection, filter by neighborhood and price\n- **MercadoLibre** - Classifieds, good for direct owner listings\n- **Facebook groups** - \"Expats in Buenos Aires\" often has sublets\n- **Walking around** - Look for \"Alquila\" (for rent) signs with phone numbers\n\n**What you'll need:**\n- Proof of income (bank statements work)\n- Passport\n- Usually 1-2 months deposit\n- Sometimes a garantía (see below)\n\n**Red flags:**\n- Asking for money before you see the place\n- Prices way below market rate\n- Pressure to decide immediately\n- No written contract offered"}]}]]}],["$","div","1",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"font-semibold flex items-center gap-3 text-lg","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"w-10 h-10 rounded-lg bg-primary/10 flex items-center justify-center","children":["$","$L39",null,{"size":"md","className":"text-primary"}]}],"The Garantía Nightmare"]}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"prose prose-sm max-w-none text-muted-foreground whitespace-pre-line","children":"The garantía is a local property owner who co-signs your lease. For foreigners, it's often impossible to get.\n\n**Your alternatives:**\n\n1. **Pay more upfront** - Offer 3-6 months deposit instead\n2. **Seguro de caución** - Insurance that acts as guarantee (about 1 month's rent)\n3. **Find flexible landlords** - Some accept foreign bank statements\n4. **Use an agency** - They sometimes have solutions for expats\n5. **Airbnb long-term** - Many negotiate monthly rates 30-40% off\n\n**Reality check:** Many expats just don't bother with formal leases. They do Airbnb long-term or find landlords willing to work without garantía. It's not ideal, but it's common."}]}]]}],["$","div","2",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6","children":"$L52"}],"$L53"]}],"$L54","$L55","$L56"]}]]}]
37:["$","$L2e",null,{"value":"week3","className":"mt-6","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"mb-6","children":[["$","h3",null,{"className":"text-2xl font-bold mb-2","children":"Week 3: Finding Your Rhythm"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"This is when it gets real. You're not a tourist anymore, but you're not quite a local either. Build your routine and your community."}]]}],["$","div",null,{"className":"space-y-6","children":[["$","div","0",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"font-semibold flex items-center gap-3 text-lg","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"w-10 h-10 rounded-lg bg-primary/10 flex items-center justify-center","children":["$","$L4f",null,{"size":"md","className":"text-primary"}]}],"Your First Asado"]}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"prose prose-sm max-w-none text-muted-foreground whitespace-pre-line","children":"You'll get invited to an asado (Argentine BBQ). This is a big deal - don't mess it up.\n\n**What to bring:**\n- Wine (Malbec or Cabernet) - never show up empty-handed\n- OR a dessert (facturas from a good bakery)\n- NOT beer (wine is the asado drink)\n\n**What to expect:**\n- Starts late (9-10pm is normal)\n- Goes for hours\n- Multiple rounds of meat\n- Lots of conversation\n- Mate might be passed around\n\n**Etiquette:**\n- Don't rush the asador (grill master)\n- Try everything offered\n- Compliment the food sincerely\n- Stay until the end if you can\n\n**Conversation topics:**\n- Football (know which team your host supports)\n- Travel\n- Food\n- Avoid: Politics, the economy (unless they bring it up)"}]}]]}],["$","div","1",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"font-semibold flex items-center gap-3 text-lg","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"w-10 h-10 rounded-lg bg-primary/10 flex items-center justify-center","children":["$","$L57",null,{"size":"md","className":"text-primary"}]}],"Mastering the SUBE"]}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"prose prose-sm max-w-none text-muted-foreground whitespace-pre-line","children":"The SUBE card is your key to the city. You'll use it for buses, subways (subte), and trains.\n\n**How it works:**\n- Tap when entering buses/subte\n- One card works for all transport\n- Can be shared (tap multiple times for multiple people)\n- Load it at kiosks, subway stations, or online\n\n**The subte lines:**\n- **Linea A** (light blue) - Historic, runs through San Telmo\n- **Linea B** (red) - Connects Palermo to center\n- **Linea D** (green) - Palermo to Congreso\n- **Linea H** (yellow) - North-south connector\n\n**Bus tips:**\n- Tell the driver your destination when boarding\n- They'll set the fare, then you tap\n- Buses run 24/7 on major routes\n- Google Maps works well for routes\n\n**Cost:** About $0.30-0.50 per ride (prices change frequently due to inflation)"}]}]]}],["$","div","2",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":["$L58","$L59"]}],"$L5a","$L5b","$L5c"]}]]}]
38:["$","$L2e",null,{"value":"week4","className":"mt-6","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"mb-6","children":[["$","h3",null,{"className":"text-2xl font-bold mb-2","children":"Week 4: Feeling Like a Local"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"You're settling in. Time to optimize, negotiate, and start thinking longer-term. You might actually know what you're doing now."}]]}],["$","div",null,{"className":"space-y-6","children":[["$","div","0",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"font-semibold flex items-center gap-3 text-lg","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"w-10 h-10 rounded-lg bg-primary/10 flex items-center justify-center","children":["$","$L2a",null,{"size":"md","className":"text-primary"}]}],"Negotiating Rent"]}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"prose prose-sm max-w-none text-muted-foreground whitespace-pre-line","children":"Yes, you can negotiate. Landlords expect it.\n\n**What you can negotiate:**\n- **Price** - Ask for 10-15% off listed price\n- **Deposit** - Try to pay 1 month instead of 2\n- **Garantía** - Offer more deposit instead\n- **Furnishings** - Ask for items you need\n- **Contract length** - Shorter terms if you're unsure\n\n**Leverage you have:**\n- Paying several months upfront\n- Foreign income (stable in USD)\n- Long-term commitment\n- No pets/no kids (if true)\n\n**How to ask:**\n\"¿Hay alguna flexibilidad en el precio?\" (Is there any flexibility on the price?)\n\n**Be ready to walk away.** There are always more apartments."}]}]]}],["$","div","1",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"font-semibold flex items-center gap-3 text-lg","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"w-10 h-10 rounded-lg bg-primary/10 flex items-center justify-center","children":["$","$L5d",null,{"size":"md","className":"text-primary"}]}],"Starting the DNI Process"]}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"prose prose-sm max-w-none text-muted-foreground whitespace-pre-line","children":"The DNI (Documento Nacional de Identidad) is your Argentine ID. It's worth getting if you're staying 6+ months.\n\n**Who qualifies:**\n- Residents (temporary or permanent)\n- Those with certain visa types\n- People born in Argentina (even if you've never lived here)\n\n**The process:**\n1. Get your residency visa approved first\n2. Make an appointment at Renaper (renaper.gob.ar)\n3. Bring: passport, visa, proof of address, birth certificate (apostilled)\n4. Get fingerprinted and photographed\n5. Wait 2-4 weeks for the card\n\n**Why bother:**\n- Easier banking\n- Local phone plans\n- Some discounts only for residents\n- You feel more official\n\n**Gestor option:** Hire an administrative helper if the bureaucracy overwhelms you. Worth every peso."}]}]]}],["$","div","2",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6","children":"$L5e"}],"$L5f"]}],"$L60","$L61"]}]]}]

This includes temporary accommodation ($600-1,200), apartment deposit ($500-1,500), food and dining ($300-600), transportation ($50-100), phone and internet ($30-60), and miscellaneous expenses ($200-400). 53:["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"prose prose-sm max-w-none text-muted-foreground whitespace-pre-line","children":"Most apartments include basic utilities in rent. Internet is usually your responsibility.\n\n**Internet providers:**\n- **Fibertel** - Most common, reliable, good speeds\n- **Telecentro** - Cheaper, decent service\n- **Flow** - Bundle with TV if you want local channels\n\n**Setup process:**\n1. Call or go to a store with your address\n2. They'll check if service is available\n3. Schedule installation (usually 3-7 days out)\n4. Technician comes to set up modem/router\n\n**Cost:** $20-35/month for 100-300 Mbps\n\n**Note:** Some buildings have existing contracts. Check with your landlord before ordering."}]}]

Even for tourist extensions, you'll end up here.\n\n**Location:** Av. Antártida Argentina 1205 (Retiro)\n\n**What to bring:**\n- Passport\n- Proof of onward travel (if extending tourist visa)\n- Any application forms you've submitted\n- Patience (lots of it)\n\n**Tips:**\n- Arrive early - lines form before opening\n- Bring a book or fully charged phone\n- Some processes require appointments online first\n- Consider hiring a \"gestor\" (administrative helper) for complex cases\n\n**For Digital Nomad Visa:** Start this process online at migraciones.gov.ar before your tourist stamp expires."}]}]]}]
55:["$","div","4",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"font-semibold flex items-center gap-3 text-lg","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"w-10 h-10 rounded-lg bg-primary/10 flex items-center justify-center","children":["$","$L2a",null,{"size":"md","className":"text-primary"}]}],"Opening a Bank Account"]}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"prose prose-sm max-w-none text-muted-foreground whitespace-pre-line","children":"Honestly? Many expats don't bother. But it can be useful for rent and utilities.\n\n**If you want to try:**\n- **Banco Galicia** - Most expat-friendly\n- **BBVA** - Good online platform\n- **Santander Río** - International connections\n\n**You'll likely need:**\n- DNI (Argentine ID) - catch-22 for new arrivals\n- Or CDI (tax ID) - easier to get\n- Proof of address\n- Proof of income\n\n**Alternative:** Many expats just use:\n- Western Union for regular transfers\n- Home country credit cards (no foreign transaction fees)\n- Cash for daily expenses\n\n**The reality:** Wait until you have residency or at least a CDI. It's not worth the hassle otherwise."}]}]]}]

Buenos Aires has great options for both.\n\n**Gyms:**\n- **Megatlon** - Premium, multiple locations, $40-60/month\n- **SportClub** - Good mid-range option\n- **SmartFit** - Budget-friendly, $15-25/month\n- **CrossFit boxes** - Every neighborhood has several\n\n**Coworking:**\n- **WeWork** - Multiple locations, familiar if you've used elsewhere\n- **La Maquinita** - Local chain, good vibes\n- **AreaTres** - Popular with startups and nomads\n- **Huerta** - Palermo, great community\n\n**Cost:** $80-150/month for coworking\n\n**Try before committing:** Most offer day passes so you can test the vibe."}]}]]}]

59:["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"prose prose-sm max-w-none text-muted-foreground whitespace-pre-line","children":"This is when Buenos Aires starts feeling like home. Find your regular places.\n\n**Your rotation should include:**\n\n**Café de confianza** - Your go-to coffee spot\n- Find one with good WiFi within walking distance\n- Go regularly, tip well, learn the staff's names\n- Eventually they'll remember your order\n\n**Panadería** - Your bakery\n- Fresh medialunas every morning\n- Try different ones until you find your favorite\n- Ask what's fresh (\"¿Qué tienen caliente?\")\n\n**Carnicería** - Your butcher\n- Quality varies wildly\n- Find one with good cuts and fair prices\n- Learn the cuts (bife de chorizo, vacío, entraña)\n\n**Verdulería** - Your produce shop\n- Better quality and prices than supermarkets\n- Build a relationship for the best stuff"}]}]
5a:["$","div","3",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"font-semibold flex items-center gap-3 text-lg","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"w-10 h-10 rounded-lg bg-primary/10 flex items-center justify-center","children":["$","$L65",null,{"size":"md","className":"text-primary"}]}],"Meeting Other Expats"]}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"prose prose-sm max-w-none text-muted-foreground whitespace-pre-line","children":"Making friends takes effort. Here's where to actually meet people:\n\n**Online to offline:**\n- **Meetup.com** - Language exchanges, hiking groups, tech meetups\n- **Internations** - Monthly events, mix of expats and locals\n- **Couchsurfing hangouts** - Even if you're not surfing\n\n**Language exchanges:**\n- **Mundo Lingo** - Weekly events, very social\n- **Conversation Exchange** - One-on-one language practice\n- **Spanglish** - Structured exchanges\n\n**Coworking communities:**\n- Many host happy hours and events\n- Great for digital nomads\n\n**Classes:**\n- Tango lessons (obviously)\n- Cooking classes\n- Yoga or fitness classes\n- Spanish group classes\n\n**Real talk:** It takes 2-3 months to build a social circle. Be patient, say yes to everything at first."}]}]]}]
5b:["$","div","4",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"font-semibold flex items-center gap-3 text-lg","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"w-10 h-10 rounded-lg bg-primary/10 flex items-center justify-center","children":["$","$L63",null,{"size":"md","className":"text-primary"}]}],"First Doctor Visit"]}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"prose prose-sm max-w-none text-muted-foreground whitespace-pre-line","children":"Sooner or later, you'll need medical care. Here's how it works:\n\n**For emergencies:**\nGo to a \"guardia\" (ER) at any hospital. Public hospitals treat everyone, but private is faster if you have insurance.\n\n**For non-emergencies:**\n- **Omint** - Good private hospital chain\n- **Hospital Alemán** - Excellent, English-speaking staff\n- **Hospital Italiano** - Top-tier care\n\n**Finding a doctor:**\n- Ask in expat groups for recommendations\n- Many doctors speak English\n- Private consultations run $30-80\n\n**Health insurance (prepaga):**\n- **OSDE** - Premium, expensive, excellent\n- **Swiss Medical** - Very good, slightly cheaper\n- **Galeno** - Good mid-range option\n- **Medicus** - Budget-friendly\n\n**Pharmacies:** Look for the green cross. Many medications available without prescription that require them elsewhere."}]}]]}]
5c:["$","div","5",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"font-semibold flex items-center gap-3 text-lg","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"w-10 h-10 rounded-lg bg-primary/10 flex items-center justify-center","children":["$","$L66",null,{"size":"md","className":"text-primary"}]}],"Dealing with Homesickness"]}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"prose prose-sm max-w-none text-muted-foreground whitespace-pre-line","children":"Week 3 is when it hits. The novelty wears off, the challenges pile up, and you miss home.\n\n**It's normal.** Everyone goes through it.\n\n**What helps:**\n- **Find your comfort foods** - There's a diaspora community for everything here. Missing Thai food? There's a place. Jewish deli food? Got it. Southern BBQ? Yep.\n- **Video calls home** - Schedule regular times\n- **English-speaking hangouts** - Sometimes you need a break from Spanish\n- **Exercise** - Gyms, running groups, yoga\n- **Routine** - Create structure in your days\n\n**Places that feel like home:**\n- **The Book Cellar** (Palermo) - English bookstore and café\n- **NOLA** (Gorriti 4389) - American-style food\n- **Any Starbucks** - I know, I know, but sometimes you need it\n\n**Remember:** This feeling passes. Month 2 is usually when things turn around."}]}]]}]
5e:["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"font-semibold flex items-center gap-3 text-lg","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"w-10 h-10 rounded-lg bg-primary/10 flex items-center justify-center","children":["$","$L50",null,{"size":"md","className":"text-primary"}]}],"Argentine Spanish (Lunfardo)"]}]
5f:["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"prose prose-sm max-w-none text-muted-foreground whitespace-pre-line","children":"Argentine Spanish is different. You'll hear words that don't exist in other Spanish-speaking countries.\n\n**Essential lunfardo:**\n- **Che** - Hey/you (used constantly)\n- **Boludo/a** - Idiot (among friends) / dude\n- **Mina** - Woman (can be neutral or slightly crude)\n- **Tipo** - Guy/dude\n- **Laburo** - Work\n- **Mufa** - Bad luck/jinx\n- **Piola** - Cool/smart\n- **Quilombo** - Mess/trouble\n\n**The \"sh\" sound:**\nArgentines pronounce \"ll\" and \"y\" like \"sh\" or \"zh\"\n- \"Calle\" sounds like \"cashe\"\n- \"Yo\" sounds like \"sho\"\n\n**Voseo:**\nThey use \"vos\" instead of \"tú\" for \"you\"\n- \"Vos tenés\" instead of \"Tú tienes\"\n- \"Vos sabés\" instead of \"Tú sabes\"\n\n**Don't worry:** You'll pick it up. Locals appreciate when you try."}]}]
60:["$","div","3",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"font-semibold flex items-center gap-3 text-lg","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"w-10 h-10 rounded-lg bg-primary/10 flex items-center justify-center","children":["$","$L28",null,{"size":"md","className":"text-primary"}]}],"Building a Routine"]}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"prose prose-sm max-w-none text-muted-foreground whitespace-pre-line","children":"By week 4, you should have some structure. Argentine schedules are different.\n\n**Typical Argentine day:**\n- **8-9am** - Breakfast (light)\n- **1-2pm** - Lunch (main meal)\n- **5-6pm** - Merienda (afternoon snack)\n- **9-10pm** - Dinner (very late by most standards)\n- **Midnight+** - Social life begins\n\n**Building your routine:**\n- Find a café for morning work/coffee\n- Schedule calls/meetings for your morning (their afternoon)\n- Embrace the late dinner - it's non-negotiable\n- Siesta isn't really a thing in Buenos Aires (unlike the provinces)\n\n**Your week might include:**\n- Language exchange meetup\n- Tango class\n- Gym routine\n- Regular asado with friends\n- Weekend feria (market) visit"}]}]]}]
61:["$","div","4",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"font-semibold flex items-center gap-3 text-lg","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"w-10 h-10 rounded-lg bg-primary/10 flex items-center justify-center","children":["$","$L39",null,{"size":"md","className":"text-primary"}]}],"When Things Go Wrong"]}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"prose prose-sm max-w-none text-muted-foreground whitespace-pre-line","children":"Stuff will go sideways. Here's who to call:\n\n**Emergencies:**\n- **911** - Police, fire, medical (works in Buenos Aires)\n- **107** - Medical emergencies\n- **101** - Fire\n\n**Police:**\n- ** Tourist Police** (Comisaría del Turista): 0800-999-5000\n  - English-speaking officers\n  - Used to dealing with foreigner issues\n\n**Your embassy:**\n- Keep their emergency number saved\n- They can help with lost passports, legal issues\n- Won't help with money or minor inconveniences\n\n**Useful apps:**\n- **BA Cómo Llego** - Public transport routes\n- **Cómo Estacionar** - Parking info\n- **Mi Argentina** - Government services\n\n**Expat groups:**\n- Facebook groups are surprisingly helpful for real-time advice\n- Someone has dealt with whatever problem you're having\n\n**Remember:** Most problems here are solvable. It just takes patience and sometimes a gestor."}]}]]}]
